channel.title: LaTeX on Pandaqi Tutorials
channel.description: Recent content in LaTeX on Pandaqi Tutorials

item.title: Introduction
item.description: The most famous text processor of this day and age, Microsoft Word, is what we call a WYSIWYG editor—What You See Is What You Get.

item.title: Installation
item.description: LaTeX is not a standalone language. It’s built on top of TeX, one of the first systems created to mark up documents.

item.title: Basic Syntax I
item.description: Because LaTeX is a markup language, the majority of your file will simply be regular text. Therefore, something is needed to tell the computer when a piece of text is actually a command.

item.title: Basic Syntax II
item.description: Continuing on last chapter, I’ll discuss some more general syntax. These will become more and more important as you get deeper into working with LaTeX.

item.title: Spaces & Reserved Characters
item.description: Like most markup languages, LaTeX collapses whitespace. When it encounters multiple spaces, it reduces them to a single one.

item.title: Basic Structure
item.description: Every document starts with the same few basic commands. Like telling Microsoft Word that you want the paper a specific size, Latex also benefits from knowing what you’re trying to do.

item.title: Document Classes
item.description: Document classes aren’t something to “understand”. You just need to know what’s out there and what options you have.

item.title: Sectioning
item.description: The first step in creating any structured project is sectioning: dividing the text into sections, subsections and paragraphs. This creates hierarchy and clarity.

item.title: Counters
item.description: As you’ve seen in last chapter, LaTeX automatically keeps separate counters for every type of section. What’s really nice is that it does the same for nearly everything—tables, figures, table of contents, and so on.

item.title: Semantics & Custom Macros
item.description: Before I start introducing command after command, I want to talk about something fundamentally important: semantics. Semantics means separating your markup and layout.

item.title: Text Formatting
item.description: These first few chapters discussed very much the global workings and overall concepts in LaTeX. How to approach a new document, how to structure a project for success, etcetera.

item.title: Languages & Special Characters
item.description: Alright, we know LaTeX will justify text, hyphenate words, and generally try to make spacing and text look as good as possible.

item.title: Footnotes, References & Citations
item.description: Any scientific or documented piece requires footnotes, references, and citations. Luckily, LaTeX was mainly created for these purposes, which means it has very good support.

item.title: Alignment & Simple Environments
item.description: This chapter will talk about some very simple environments that are quite important. They are nothing fancy or complicated.

item.title: Fonts
item.description: LaTeX has its own default font—Computer Modern—which looks great everywhere and in any size. It will be completely fine for most use cases.

item.title: Lists
item.description: Even if your paragraphs are of the highest typographical quality, some things are better expressed using lists. As the name implies: they are ideal for listing numerous things.

item.title: Spacing
item.description: These default lists and settings are great. But it’s easily possible that you need different amounts of space between items, or more horizontal distance between label and item text.

item.title: Lengths
item.description: Last chapter discussed the various ways you can add or remove extra space at any moment. This chapter will talk about the other side of that coin: the basic lengths that are applied throughout the whole document.

item.title: Tables I
item.description: Tables are an invaluable tool for presenting data in a clean way. But they always come with a few complications.

item.title: Tables II
item.description: Last chapter introduced the basic concepts needed for a table. But we’re still stuck with a few tiny disadvantages.

item.title: Floats & Protection
item.description: The subjects from the title are completely unrelated. But they were too short to receive their own chapter, which is why I’ll discuss both at once.

item.title: Multiple Columns
item.description: Columns aren’t natively supported by LaTeX. I know, that strange typesetting language keeps throwing curveballs. But they are easily included with the help of the package multicol.

item.title: Hyperlinks & URLs
item.description: At the time TeX was introduced, hyperlinks and URLs weren’t as mainstream as they are now. That’s why any support for these has to come from a nifty little package called hyperref.

item.title: Figures & Images
item.description: We’ve already seen the table environment. It does nothing more than contain a table and any metadata, such as a caption or reference.

item.title: Special Pages I
item.description: We’ve already briefly seen the title page and table of contents at the start of every document. But there are more special pages that are usually included in LaTeX documents.

item.title: Special Pages II
item.description: Continuing on last chapter, here are the two other quite important special pages. The main purpose of LaTeX was to easily write clear and beautiful (scientific) papers or lasting documents for global consumption.

item.title: Pages Layouts & Margin
item.description: Until now we’ve silently accepted the size of the margins LaTeX decides. Not anymore! Let’s look changing the amount of white space around your document.

item.title: Conclusion: what now?
item.description: Congratulations! You’re a LaTeX wizard now ✨ You’ve seen and played with the fundamentals of LaTeX. Even some slightly advanced topics.
